description: These episodes are designed to demystify the world of cryptography. One will hear about the different aspects of cryptography, associated terminology, different types of cryptography, applications to it and other topics ranging from the history of cryptography, to high-level concepts like ciphers and key exchanges. Discover practical applications of cryptography and how it is applied to various areas in the field of security.
name: Cryptography
subtitle: An in-depth look into cryptography concepts

28

30

31

37
00:02:23.941 --> 00:02:26.760

00:03:10.455 --> 00:03:13.525
I mean there's much, much,

50
00:03:13.525 --> 00:03:18.525
substantially larger, more than you can

00:03:18.525 --> 00:03:21.855

00:03:40.155 --> 00:03:43.270

00:03:43.270 --> 00:03:48.370

ones, like the Caesar cipher.

59
00:03:48.370 --> 00:03:52.475
Some comes in, some comes out that's
been transformed or it can be reversed.

60
00:03:52.475 --> 00:03:56.370
And, so that's, that's a big-

00:03:56.370 --> 00:03:58.370
formulas that we remember
from network plus, right?

00:03:58.370 --> 00:03:59.790
When we're doing our subnetting?

00:03:59.790 --> 00:04:05.160
With your Cesar cipher for example you
got 26 or 27 keys in your key space,

if we take a AES256 well that's 256

65
00:04:12.850 --> 00:04:16.920
So I can do a formula two
to the 256 power, and

66
00:04:16.920 --> 00:04:20.180
that could tell me how many
possible keys are in there.

67
00:04:20.180 --> 00:04:23.830
Assuming that the algorithm allows

68
00:04:23.830 --> 00:04:26.650
But yeah, that's quite a large key space.

69
00:04:26.650 --> 00:04:28.980
And the point is,

00:04:33.370 --> 00:04:35.860
At least by the time I

75

>> [LAUGH] There you go.

76
00:04:46.661 --> 00:04:47.473

84
00:05:02.042 --> 00:05:06.938
there's plenty of situations

00:05:06.938 --> 00:05:10.388
They define a large key space

00:05:10.388 --> 00:05:14.663
then they actually block out parts
some of those keys from being used

87
00:05:14.663 --> 00:05:17.602
because they're pointless

00:05:34.904 --> 00:05:36.620
[LAUGH]

00:05:36.620 --> 00:05:40.473
>> Cuz the plaintext and
the ciphertext is gonna look very similar,

00:05:40.473 --> 00:05:41.954

96
00:05:41.954 --> 00:05:42.491
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

97
00:05:42.491 --> 00:05:44.970
>> And that's a little problem there, so

98
00:05:44.970 --> 00:05:46.999
yeah, you would discard that,

00:05:46.999 --> 00:05:50.694

00:05:55.330 --> 00:05:57.794
Get it out of there so

103
00:06:00.537 --> 00:06:04.578
A key space of a certain size but

00:06:04.578 --> 00:06:09.516

105
00:06:09.516 --> 00:06:12.839

00:06:19.002 --> 00:06:20.627

00:07:07.780 --> 00:07:12.161
Those things can result in maybe

00:07:15.543 --> 00:07:19.393
So that leads to some of the stuff we
talked like yesterday, which we're

00:07:23.750 --> 00:07:29.586

30

31
00:02:08.990 --> 00:02:12.880

32

33
00:02:16.560 --> 00:02:21.100

34
00:02:21.100 --> 00:02:26.980

38

00:02:45.216 --> 00:02:50.087

But here, we're gonna make that

47
00:03:15.660 --> 00:03:18.280
they've kind of sort of

48
00:03:18.280 --> 00:03:20.470
Notice Caesar cipher.

49
00:03:21.480 --> 00:03:26.120
That is what it's called,

50
00:03:26.120 --> 00:03:29.830
called it an algorithm because I

51
00:03:29.830 --> 00:03:32.890
Okay, that actually works.

52
00:03:32.890 --> 00:03:36.320
There's also these things

53
00:03:36.320 --> 00:03:40.094
A substitution cipher and
transposition cipher,

54
00:03:40.094 --> 00:03:44.290
those things there's really
not a formula for them.

55
00:03:44.290 --> 00:03:47.810
You really can't quantify
them as an algorithm.

56
00:03:47.810 --> 00:03:49.290
An algorithm is a formula.

57
00:03:49.290 --> 00:03:54.130
But you can use the techniques
of transposition in substitution

58
00:03:54.130 --> 00:03:55.260
within an algorithm.

59
00:03:55.260 --> 00:03:57.411
Which is what the Caesar cipher does.

60
00:03:57.411 --> 00:04:01.375
A Caesar cipher takes those techniques and
plugs them in.

61
00:04:01.375 --> 00:04:04.222
And says, okay, well,
I'm going to substitute things, but

62
00:04:04.222 --> 00:04:08.060

63
00:04:08.060 --> 00:04:09.905

65
00:04:14.360 --> 00:04:18.726

00:04:23.435 --> 00:04:25.600

00:04:35.050 --> 00:04:37.060
Substitutions and
transpositions inside of it.

00:04:37.060 --> 00:04:40.930

72
00:04:40.930 --> 00:04:46.240

a little other magic put in.

73
00:04:46.240 --> 00:04:49.930
But you get those all mixed in,

74
00:04:49.930 --> 00:04:53.472
So they didn't just use
one Rijndael algorithm,

75
00:04:53.472 --> 00:04:57.619
you get all these things put

76
00:04:57.619 --> 00:05:02.456
And it works quite effectively,

00:05:02.456 --> 00:05:07.925

78
00:05:07.925 --> 00:05:08.445
>> Very good.

79
00:05:08.445 --> 00:05:09.175
All right.

80

So we had an idea of what makes
an algorithm, what makes a cipher, and

81

then in the general sense a lot of times

82

the difference between them so

83
00:05:20.662 --> 00:05:23.225
that when needed we can be
very specific when we say,

84
00:05:23.225 --> 00:05:26.950
okay, this is what a cipher is and

85
00:05:26.950 --> 00:05:28.760
>> Yeah, and just be aware.

86
00:05:28.760 --> 00:05:32.350
They are used very much interchangeably.

87
00:05:32.350 --> 00:05:36.410
If you're at a very basic level, and

just starting out in it, you can get

89
00:05:40.910 --> 00:05:44.220

00:05:44.220 --> 00:05:49.590
unless they're specifically

91
00:05:49.590 --> 00:05:55.174

92
00:05:55.174 --> 00:05:57.390
that's about it.

93
00:05:57.390 --> 00:06:00.390
So algorithm by far is

94
00:06:00.390 --> 00:06:02.940
there actually are two

95
00:06:02.940 --> 00:06:07.970
There is algorithm, there is a cipher and

96
00:06:07.970 --> 00:06:11.385
You got to kinda be careful with that
if you get into it at some point.

97
00:06:11.385 --> 00:06:14.732
And those that are going to
pursue this topic further,

98
00:06:14.732 --> 00:06:18.890
which that might be what a good amount

00:06:25.290 --> 00:06:26.840
I know Caltech has a bunch of them.

104
00:06:33.320 --> 00:06:36.390
And so if you think they're same thing,
everybody like whoa, whoa, whoa.

105
00:06:36.390 --> 00:06:38.890
What happened, what are they doing here?

106
00:06:38.890 --> 00:06:42.250
You have to remember they're
referring to two different

107
00:06:42.250 --> 00:06:44.320
things there that are related.

108
00:06:44.320 --> 00:06:49.950
But they're definitely not the same
thing and just be careful.

109
00:06:49.950 --> 00:06:57.080
When you see the two, that you do not
get caught on one versus the other.

110
00:06:57.080 --> 00:07:01.415
>> All right, and then when we talk about
types of systems, we've mentioned these

111
00:07:01.415 --> 00:07:05.126
terms already a couple of times,
but let's break those down again.

112
00:07:05.126 --> 00:07:09.040
Cuz during this episode, we're gonna
really dive into each one of these, and

113
00:07:09.040 --> 00:07:13.017
discuss the differences and what makes
them tick, and what their strengths and

114
00:07:13.017 --> 00:07:14.220
weaknesses are.

115
00:07:14.220 --> 00:07:17.010
Well, let's start by just
defining these terms here.

116
00:07:17.010 --> 00:07:22.460
Yes, we do have to define what it is
we're going to be talking about here.

117
00:07:22.460 --> 00:07:25.604
In this particular when
we talk about algorithms,

118
00:07:25.604 --> 00:07:31.270
we're gonna be focusing on two types of
algorithms, symmetric and asymmetric.

119
00:07:31.270 --> 00:07:37.940
And those are the two major types that
are gonna be seen in the world nowadays.

120
00:07:37.940 --> 00:07:41.540
Now, they come in a tremendous amount
of different flavors out there.

121
00:07:41.540 --> 00:07:46.730
So it's not just one type of symmetric or
one type of asymmetric.

122
00:07:46.730 --> 00:07:50.380
There's many different ways to
carry those techniques out.

123
00:07:50.380 --> 00:07:54.125
It just depends on the specific
algorithm we're using to carry that out.

124
00:07:54.125 --> 00:07:58.824
But symmetric, one of the things they
also do tend to call it is they do

125
00:07:58.824 --> 00:08:01.021
tend to call it in some circles.

126
00:08:01.021 --> 00:08:03.960
Classic cryptography.

127
00:08:03.960 --> 00:08:08.351
And if you look at it,

00:08:08.351 --> 00:08:11.590

00:08:11.590 --> 00:08:17.310

136

key to encrypt and

And the two can work

00:09:15.389 --> 00:09:21.330

It's one of those, I find symmetric

There was a symmetric cipher

00:10:00.590 --> 00:10:06.010
And so, there was records being kept that

00:10:06.010 --> 00:10:10.570

158
00:10:10.570 --> 00:10:16.382

159
00:10:16.382 --> 00:10:23.012
So, it started falling into lesser and
lesser decreased usage over time.

160

that someone lost the knowledge and

keys of how to use the system.

And oops.

it's gonna be a little difficult to get

I guess you pretty much just have

>> Yeah and I guess the system was
designed so well that brute forcing,

while it can be done with any system,
it was gonna be insanely tough.

183
00:11:46.844 --> 00:11:50.888
And just everything else you could say
with a level of technology they had at

184

that time.

185

And so now-
>> [CROSSTALK] space and

00:11:54.343 --> 00:11:57.728
that's gonna take a long time
>> Yeah, and so they had a big,

big problem on their hands.

188

So it's almost like a period of time in

00:12:06.880 --> 00:12:09.780
Nothing happened in France for

190
00:12:09.780 --> 00:12:14.680
So, but it also,
to talk about something from

00:12:14.680 --> 00:12:17.950
the previous episode,
that's kind of Kirkoff's Principle too.

It's something that should be

That was a problem that they encountered.

I don't think they're the only

this come up heads three times in a row,

1023

>> Yeah.

1025
00:55:03.900 --> 00:55:07.450
Those are all independent situations,

1026

Strictly the results of that one are

1027
00:55:12.190 --> 00:55:14.380
What happens before or

00:55:14.380 --> 00:55:16.960

1039

That's not part of this, okay, so

00:56:06.670 --> 00:56:09.960

00:56:11.940 --> 00:56:15.950

1050
00:56:19.180 --> 00:56:22.250

1051
00:56:22.250 --> 00:56:25.950

1052
00:56:25.950 --> 00:56:30.290
time pad using a key, and

1053
00:56:30.290 --> 00:56:34.260

00:56:34.260 --> 00:56:37.980

1055
00:56:37.980 --> 00:56:39.480

1056
00:56:39.480 --> 00:56:43.850

00:57:05.470 --> 00:57:09.420

because of that, it's not really a very

So it's kind of a tough concept sometimes,

>> Yeah, and I think it's a fair point for

36
00:02:17.770 --> 00:02:23.296
Because yeah, as soon as you introduce
that concept and say it is encrypting,

37
00:02:23.296 --> 00:02:28.590
then you immediately go down the line of,

38
00:02:28.590 --> 00:02:33.405

39

00:02:40.485 --> 00:02:44.610

00:02:44.610 --> 00:02:49.220
It creates a what they call a hash or

43
00:02:49.220 --> 00:02:52.630

00:02:58.280 --> 00:03:03.320

46
00:03:03.320 --> 00:03:07.340
So, yeah, it's not designed to do

47
00:03:07.340 --> 00:03:11.296
It's designed to do something different,
tackle a different problem,

48
00:03:11.296 --> 00:03:14.560
which is the integrity problem,
or detect modifications.

49
00:03:14.560 --> 00:03:19.477
And don't kid yourself though, while
it doesn't protect confidentiality and

50
00:03:19.477 --> 00:03:23.970
it only does integrity, it is significant
what this brings to the table.

51
00:03:23.970 --> 00:03:27.730
I mean, there's just a tremendous
amount of things you can do with this.

52
00:03:27.730 --> 00:03:31.300

00:03:55.170 --> 00:03:58.380

cuz most of us have probably

33
00:01:59.050 --> 00:02:04.340
>> So we'll start off talking about just

34
00:02:04.340 --> 00:02:07.293
And as Sean mentioned,
if you're unfamiliar with public key

35
00:02:07.293 --> 00:02:10.584
infrastructure or PKI, go take a look

38
00:02:16.280 --> 00:02:18.714
But we should have a good
understanding of PKI.

39
00:02:18.714 --> 00:02:22.500
Public key infrastructures really are all
the different components that allow us to

40
00:02:22.500 --> 00:02:27.010
manage those digital certificates
throughout their lifetime, issuing them,

41
00:02:27.010 --> 00:02:30.790
managing and maintaining them,
revoking them when necessary,

42
00:02:30.790 --> 00:02:32.940
renewing them when necessary.

43
00:02:32.940 --> 00:02:37.140
So it's really all the different
pieces involved in that process.

44
00:02:37.140 --> 00:02:40.898
And remember, the thing is
the certificate, digital or electronic

45
00:02:40.898 --> 00:02:45.710
document that's proving your identity, but
also tying your identity to the key pair.

46
00:02:45.710 --> 00:02:51.060
We've talked about asymmetric encryption
algorithms and then we get a key pair.

47
00:02:51.060 --> 00:02:55.480
We have two different keys,
a public key and a private key.

48
00:02:55.480 --> 00:02:56.910
Where do we get those?

49
00:02:56.910 --> 00:02:58.530
I didn't go down to the hardware store and
say,

50
00:02:58.530 --> 00:03:01.260
hey can I get a copy of a public key or
a private key.

51
00:03:01.260 --> 00:03:03.550
We need something that generates those and

52
00:03:03.550 --> 00:03:06.680
public key infrastructure is one
of the things that can do that.

53
00:03:06.680 --> 00:03:10.130
>> Yes, it does a whole lot.

54
00:03:10.130 --> 00:03:11.222
There's just so

55
00:03:11.222 --> 00:03:15.670
many things that it's embedded into
that you just may not realize.

56
00:03:15.670 --> 00:03:21.090
It's embedded into or it's an integral
part of stuff like eCommerce.

57
00:03:21.090 --> 00:03:25.510
Because that ain't happening
without something like PKI.

58
00:03:25.510 --> 00:03:29.960
We have different forms of file exchange
with encryption that fits them there.

59
00:03:29.960 --> 00:03:32.280
STL, TLS come to mind.

60
00:03:32.280 --> 00:03:35.050
Then there's VPN, there's IP sack.

61
00:03:35.050 --> 00:03:37.050
You could keep going on and on.

62
00:03:37.050 --> 00:03:42.410
Digital signatures are a big user of this.

63
00:03:42.410 --> 00:03:45.740
And you get even those
identity cards that they

64
00:03:45.740 --> 00:03:49.620
use in some government organizations
that have the chip in them, and

65
00:03:49.620 --> 00:03:54.450
they store certificates on it or
keys and certificates on it.

66
00:03:54.450 --> 00:03:59.960
So there's a broad range of
things that use this technology.

67
00:03:59.960 --> 00:04:05.720
And they use it in different ways,
but the primary thing is that yes

68
00:04:05.720 --> 00:04:10.710
it was generating key pairs and
then tying one of those keys,

69
00:04:10.710 --> 00:04:15.330
being the public key, tying it back to
an identity through a digital certificate.

70
00:04:15.330 --> 00:04:19.860
And so it can not only create that,
it can validate, revoke it, manage it.

71
00:04:19.860 --> 00:04:21.840
There's the whole things
that go with that.

72
00:04:21.840 --> 00:04:24.670
PKI is not, so we're clear about it,

73
00:04:24.670 --> 00:04:29.630
it's not something that you just
set up for the sake of setting up.

74
00:04:29.630 --> 00:04:30.800
It's not one of those things.

75
00:04:30.800 --> 00:04:32.607
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's something

76
00:04:32.607 --> 00:04:34.530
that you set up to be used in
one of these other things.

77
00:04:34.530 --> 00:04:36.590
It doesn't really do anything by itself.

78
00:04:36.590 --> 00:04:43.000
If there's not something actively engaging
it, it just sits there and takes up space.

79
00:04:43.000 --> 00:04:46.960
>> Really need to have some reason
to set up public infrastructure.

80
00:04:46.960 --> 00:04:51.331
There are a lot of different pieces and
parts typically that make up the PKI or

81
00:04:51.331 --> 00:04:53.420
public key infrastructure.

82
00:04:53.420 --> 00:04:55.810
Big one being what we call
a certificate authority.

83
00:04:55.810 --> 00:05:00.207
That's the server, the machine or
the device that's actually issuing,

84
00:05:00.207 --> 00:05:04.760
generating and then issuing these
certificates and these public key pairs.

85
00:05:04.760 --> 00:05:09.395
>> Yeah exactly, that's all it is is
just something that acts as the main

86
00:05:09.395 --> 00:05:11.920
authority for that's, it's name.

87
00:05:11.920 --> 00:05:17.244
It takes the role of creating the key
pairs, the certificates that go with it,

88
00:05:17.244 --> 00:05:21.841
and then being the reference point
where people can go to to validate

89
00:05:21.841 --> 00:05:26.140
something when they are,
validate whatever operation.

90
00:05:26.140 --> 00:05:29.896
When someone gives them something
that says hey, you don't know me, but

91
00:05:29.896 --> 00:05:34.076
there's somebody else out here that knows
me that you happen to trust as well, and

92
00:05:34.076 --> 00:05:35.120
you can go ask them.

93
00:05:35.120 --> 00:05:37.742
And then you pull the certificate, and

94
00:05:37.742 --> 00:05:41.650
go though the validation process and
all that good stuff.

95
00:05:41.650 --> 00:05:46.130
So that's what a certificate authority is,
and then there's different levels of that.

96
00:05:46.130 --> 00:05:49.000
And then there's
registration authorities and

97
00:05:49.000 --> 00:05:51.380
all sorts of things that come into play.

98
00:05:51.380 --> 00:05:54.360
>> Yeah, you can kind of break it
up into individual components.

99
00:05:54.360 --> 00:05:57.420
And depending, like in a Windows
environment, the registration authority

100
00:05:57.420 --> 00:05:59.600
and the certificate authority
are typically the same thing.

101
00:05:59.600 --> 00:06:03.910
But when we talk about it logically,
they are individual components.

102
00:06:03.910 --> 00:06:07.630
And one of the primary things that
it has to do is identify you.

103
00:06:07.630 --> 00:06:12.400
We have to prove, I can't just go and get
a certificate that says, I'm Sean Oriyano.

104
00:06:12.400 --> 00:06:16.645
Because they're gonna wanna make sure that
I truly am Sean Oriyano before they issue

105
00:06:16.645 --> 00:06:21.217
that certificate whether that's and again,
we're not gonna dive into PKI completely.

106
00:06:21.217 --> 00:06:25.312
But whether that's a public certificate
server, certificate authority or

107
00:06:25.312 --> 00:06:27.958
a private or
an internal certificate authority,

108
00:06:27.958 --> 00:06:31.864
that verification has to be there
because really, when comes down to it,

109
00:06:31.864 --> 00:06:35.480
public key infrastructure,
PKI, it's all based on trust.

110
00:06:35.480 --> 00:06:38.100
You have to trust the issuing party.

111
00:06:38.100 --> 00:06:41.520
If I don't trust the person that
the certificate came from or whoever

112
00:06:41.520 --> 00:06:45.770
the issuing authority was, I should say,
then I'm not gonna trust the certificate.

113
00:06:45.770 --> 00:06:49.350
If you think about like SSL, and
me going to Bank of America and

114
00:06:49.350 --> 00:06:50.790
do my online banking.

115
00:06:50.790 --> 00:06:53.670
Well the first thing that happens
when I connect to that web server,

116
00:06:53.670 --> 00:06:55.560
is I request Bank of America certificate.

117
00:06:55.560 --> 00:06:57.440
And we talked about that the other day.

118
00:06:57.440 --> 00:07:02.380
That's how I'm gonna get Bank of America's
public key, and prove the identity

119
00:07:02.380 --> 00:07:06.340
of that Bank of America web server,
that it actually is Bank of America.

120
00:07:06.340 --> 00:07:09.300
But what my computer does when
it gets that certificate back.

121
00:07:09.300 --> 00:07:11.370
It doesn't just trust it immediately.

122
00:07:11.370 --> 00:07:13.280
It looks at the issuing party.

123
00:07:13.280 --> 00:07:16.940
And on there, there's a signature which
is something else we've talked about

124
00:07:16.940 --> 00:07:20.935
in our previous episodes, there's
a signature from the issuing authority.

125
00:07:20.935 --> 00:07:25.845
Let's say it's Verisign, I'm not sure
who Bank of America actually uses, but

126
00:07:25.845 --> 00:07:28.495
then what my computer is going to do
is it's going to see that signature and

127
00:07:28.495 --> 00:07:30.705
say okay this was issued by Verisign.

128
00:07:30.705 --> 00:07:34.435
My browser, in the case of Windows,
my Internet Explorer has a list

129
00:07:34.435 --> 00:07:38.755
of trusted certification authorities,
Verisign is on that list.

130
00:07:38.755 --> 00:07:41.290
Then I'm gonna trust
the CA that issued it.

131
00:07:41.290 --> 00:07:43.780
My computer trusts Verisign therefore
it trusts that certificate,

132
00:07:43.780 --> 00:07:47.930
but it doesn't stop there,
it does validate the certificate as well.

133
00:07:47.930 --> 00:07:51.712
Now, it's gonna go talk to Verisign and
say hey, this server just presented me

134
00:07:51.712 --> 00:07:54.263
this certificate,
is this certificate still good?

135
00:07:54.263 --> 00:07:55.970
Because it could be expired.

136
00:07:55.970 --> 00:07:56.690
Maybe they didn't renew it.

137
00:07:56.690 --> 00:07:59.310
It could be revoked for some reason.

138
00:07:59.310 --> 00:08:01.260
Maybe it's no longer trusted.

139
00:08:01.260 --> 00:08:06.850
So I'd have to verify that
the certificate itself is still valid.

140
00:08:06.850 --> 00:08:11.908
>> Yeah, while you're talking about
that Mike, just so you guys can kind of

141
00:08:11.908 --> 00:08:17.051
understand what a certificate looks

00:08:17.051 --> 00:08:21.074

143
00:08:21.074 --> 00:08:24.110

going to pop one up here on my screen.

00:08:32.010 --> 00:08:35.560
What I see is I see

00:08:35.560 --> 00:08:41.710

being used for my start page site.

147
00:08:41.710 --> 00:08:46.549
And what I have is I can see on there,
I can see validity dates.

148
00:08:46.549 --> 00:08:48.267
So that's what Mike was
just talking about.

149

WEBVTT

1

2

3
00:00:22.353 --> 00:00:32.963
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:32.963 --> 00:00:34.890
Good morning, good afternoon and
good evening.

5
00:00:34.890 --> 00:00:37.380
Welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:37.380 --> 00:00:39.330
I'm your host Mike Rodrick and
with me today is Mr.

7
00:00:39.330 --> 00:00:41.120
Sean Oriyano, how you doing Sean?

8
00:00:41.120 --> 00:00:42.070
>> Doing pretty good, how about you?

9
00:00:42.070 --> 00:00:43.655
>> I am doing fantastic,

10
00:00:43.655 --> 00:00:47.540
cuz we have more of our cryptography
episodes coming your way.

11
00:00:47.540 --> 00:00:51.300
Today we are gonna cover steganography.

12
00:00:51.300 --> 00:00:55.759
Pretty interesting topic here Sean,
it fits right along it's just another type

13
00:00:55.759 --> 00:00:58.920
of, well, it does fit into
our cryptography episodes.

14
00:00:58.920 --> 00:01:01.518
A little bit different though
than what we're used to, or

15
00:01:01.518 --> 00:01:04.130
what we've dealt with in our
previous episodes, right?

16
00:01:04.130 --> 00:01:08.520
>> Yes, it is decidedly different
than anything we've had before.

17
00:01:08.520 --> 00:01:13.009
Now, it can be used in combination
with the stuff that we saw before, and

18
00:01:13.009 --> 00:01:15.890
it frequently is, but
it doesn't have to be.

19
00:01:15.890 --> 00:01:19.600
So it's something that just kinda
fits under that same banner.

20
00:01:19.600 --> 00:01:24.313
And it does tackle certain goals and
accomplish certain tasks that,

21
00:01:24.313 --> 00:01:28.800
just regular cryptography as we know it so
far, just can't do.

22
00:01:28.800 --> 00:01:31.030
No matter whether you're
talking classical or

23
00:01:31.030 --> 00:01:34.170
you're talking modern,
they just can't do it.

24
00:01:34.170 --> 00:01:37.260
They can't do the same thing that
steganography can so it solves or

25
00:01:37.260 --> 00:01:39.600
takes care of a very unique problem.

26
00:01:39.600 --> 00:01:42.830
So that's what we have going on here.

27
00:01:42.830 --> 00:01:46.262
>> Yeah, it's a little different
because with cryptography,

28
00:01:46.262 --> 00:01:50.222
we're encrypting this plaintext,
turning it into ciphertext so that

29
00:01:50.222 --> 00:01:54.845
it's not readable without the proper keys
to be able to decrypt that information.

30
00:01:54.845 --> 00:01:56.975
But you can still see that
the information is there.

31
00:01:56.975 --> 00:02:01.311
If you think about it, if you encrypt
a file on your hard drive using EFS or

32
00:02:01.311 --> 00:02:05.861
my encrypting file system, part of NTFS,
the file is still there, right,

33
00:02:05.861 --> 00:02:08.795
it turns green to show
you that it's encrypted.

34
00:02:08.795 --> 00:02:11.877
And if you try to double click on it,
you can't open it if you

35
00:02:11.877 --> 00:02:15.990
don't have the right key, but
you can still see the file is still there.

36
00:02:15.990 --> 00:02:19.010
Steganography takes a different approach,
right?

37
00:02:19.010 --> 00:02:22.140
It's not taking plaintext and
turning it into ciphertext.

38
00:02:22.140 --> 00:02:24.070
What are we doing with steganography?

39
00:02:24.070 --> 00:02:28.585
>> Steganography, to give you kind
of a clue to where it's going, if

40
00:02:28.585 --> 00:02:33.065
you're unaware of it, is they frequently
refer to as hiding in plain sight.

41
00:02:33.065 --> 00:02:38.795
Which really kind of sums up the whole
concept once you understand it.

42
00:02:38.795 --> 00:02:41.395
That's really it,
is you are hiding in plain sight.

43
00:02:41.395 --> 00:02:43.217
And what you're doing
with steganography is,

44
00:02:43.217 --> 00:02:45.610
we're doing a little bit of
a terminology shift here.

45
00:02:45.610 --> 00:02:50.260
What we do is we're embedding
something inside of something else.

46
00:02:50.260 --> 00:02:54.516
And what that is, is we're embedding
something like plaintext or

47
00:02:54.516 --> 00:02:57.708
a payload inside something
they call cover text,

48
00:02:57.708 --> 00:03:02.510
which is the actual item that is gonna
be holding this hidden information.

49
00:03:02.510 --> 00:03:06.806
Now how you get that information,
that secret that you want and

50
00:03:06.806 --> 00:03:11.040
weave it into this other item is,
there's many techniques.

51
00:03:11.040 --> 00:03:15.080
Let's just put it out there, many
different techniques to accomplish that.

52
00:03:15.080 --> 00:03:19.587
But no matter which way you look at it,
you are doing something in such a way that

53
00:03:19.587 --> 00:03:24.031
someone looking at that without
knowledge that something's hidden there,

54
00:03:24.031 --> 00:03:26.100
is just not gonna know it's there.

55
00:03:26.100 --> 00:03:29.130
They're gonna go right on by and
treat it at face value.

56
00:03:29.130 --> 00:03:34.280
They're not gonna look for these other
little details kind of hidden in there.

57
00:03:34.280 --> 00:03:38.880
>> So I might take a secret formula
that I have, and I might choose to

58
00:03:38.880 --> 00:03:43.260
use steganography and embed that
data into an image, for example.

59
00:03:43.260 --> 00:03:45.750
And now that image doesn't change, and

60
00:03:45.750 --> 00:03:48.680
it's not perceivable to
the human eye anyway.

61
00:03:48.680 --> 00:03:51.992
So now you might go to my computer or
you might pop in my thumb drive and

62
00:03:51.992 --> 00:03:54.680
you see a picture, and
it looks like a normal picture.

63
00:03:54.680 --> 00:03:58.260
And you double click on it and it opens
up and you can look at the picture.

64
00:03:58.260 --> 00:04:00.900
No problem, because you don't even know,

65
00:04:00.900 --> 00:04:05.740
there's no indication that there's
any data hidden within that image.

66
00:04:05.740 --> 00:04:09.380
So, as you said, we're just hiding
it right there in plain sight.

67
00:04:09.380 --> 00:04:11.690
And the data's not encrypted, right, Sean?

68
00:04:11.690 --> 00:04:16.450
It's not encrypted, it doesn't have to be-
>> But it can.

69
00:04:16.450 --> 00:04:20.800
>> Yeah, most programs will do that
as an extra layer of protection.

70
00:04:20.800 --> 00:04:23.710
What they'll do is they'll take the file,
run it through something, and

71
00:04:23.710 --> 00:04:27.930
then take whatever that is and
put it inside the cover text.

72
00:04:27.930 --> 00:04:31.420
>> So I might take my plaintext,
convert it to ciphertext, and

73
00:04:31.420 --> 00:04:33.920
then embed my ciphertext into an image.

74
00:04:33.920 --> 00:04:36.092
So first you gotta find out
that the data's even there.

75
00:04:36.092 --> 00:04:41.260
You've gotta somehow realize that this
picture contains additional information.

76
00:04:41.260 --> 00:04:42.910
And even if you do figure that out and

77
00:04:42.910 --> 00:04:45.690
you're able to extract that,
you've extracted encrypted text.

78
00:04:45.690 --> 00:04:48.300
And now you've gotta somehow break
that encryption that's on there.

79
00:04:48.300 --> 00:04:50.170
So it can act like a second layer.

80
00:04:50.170 --> 00:04:53.646
>> Yeah they can do many
transformations on it before

81
00:04:53.646 --> 00:04:58.960
they even get to the point of
embedding it inside this cover text.

82
00:04:58.960 --> 00:05:04.110
Invisible Secrets would be one that
we've seen in prior classes that,

83
00:05:04.110 --> 00:05:07.860
what it does, is it actually takes
the information, compresses it,

84
00:05:07.860 --> 00:05:13.070
encrypts it, and then sticks it
inside of an image of your choosing.

85
00:05:13.070 --> 00:05:15.740
So you can see it's doing
two operations there.

86
00:05:15.740 --> 00:05:22.180
And so yeah, you're right, if someone were
able to detect it, that's the first step.

87
00:05:22.180 --> 00:05:23.900
They have to detect that it's there.

88
00:05:23.900 --> 00:05:27.130
Once they detect it and
they extract the information,

89
00:05:27.130 --> 00:05:31.490
the next thing is that now they got
to break that key, whatever it is.

90
00:05:31.490 --> 00:05:35.713
And if you're talking about
Invisible Secrets, they use AES and

91
00:05:35.713 --> 00:05:38.260
we already know what the deal is there.

92
00:05:38.260 --> 00:05:42.386
So they've really bumped things up
on you way, way, way, way, way up.

93
00:05:42.386 --> 00:05:45.020
>> So steganography, again,
it gives me the ability

94
00:05:45.020 --> 00:05:49.500
to hide that information in plain sight,
and so what the bad guys are doing, or

95
00:05:49.500 --> 00:05:52.380
maybe the good guys,
trying to keep it from the bad guys.

96
00:05:52.380 --> 00:05:54.690
Again, if somebody was to
examine my thumb drive,

97
00:05:54.690 --> 00:05:58.556
they'd see a whole series of pictures,
or a bunch of MP3 files.

98
00:05:58.556 --> 00:06:02.070
And so if I, hopefully, the idea

99
00:06:02.070 --> 00:06:06.130
is that they're not gonna realize that
there's additional data embedded in there.

100
00:06:06.130 --> 00:06:07.570
And this is not a new technique, right?

101
00:06:07.570 --> 00:06:11.650
This has been going on, just as we talked
about, encryption has been going on since,

102
00:06:11.650 --> 00:06:13.710
we know of,
all the way back to the Egyptian days.

103
00:06:13.710 --> 00:06:15.750
Most likely further than that.

104
00:06:15.750 --> 00:06:17.800
Steganography is not new, as well.

105
00:06:17.800 --> 00:06:20.930
>> Yeah, it's been there for
a long, long, long time.

106
00:06:20.930 --> 00:06:27.980
It just maybe hasn't been given a name,
or whatever you want to call it,

107
00:06:27.980 --> 00:06:32.870
but it's gone under a lot, come in a lot
of different forms over the years.

108
00:06:32.870 --> 00:06:37.050
And they always do the same thing
no matter where you see it.

109
00:06:37.050 --> 00:06:41.110
It hides something in such a way that
unless you deliberately know it's

110
00:06:41.110 --> 00:06:43.340
there and go looking for it,
you're not gonna see it.

111
00:06:43.340 --> 00:06:47.580
Which is the big benefit that it has,
by the way, over standard cryptography.

112
00:06:47.580 --> 00:06:51.150
Cryptography encrypts something,
as you're saying, you know it's encrypted.

113
00:06:51.150 --> 00:06:56.330
You were mentioning that in Windows
it turns the files a different color.

114
00:06:56.330 --> 00:07:02.439
Even if it wasn't that, if you looked at a
piece of plaintext and see it's encrypted,

115
00:07:02.439 --> 00:07:08.480
you immediately are gonna say, okay
they're trying to keep something from me.

116
00:07:08.480 --> 00:07:10.720
So it's immediately got your attention.

117
00:07:10.720 --> 00:07:15.020
Steganography counters that by saying, I'm
just not gonna let you know it's there.

118
00:07:15.020 --> 00:07:19.310
I could encrypt it as well, but
I'm gonna encrypt it before I embed it.

119
00:07:19.310 --> 00:07:21.980
Therefore, it doesn't draw
your attention to it, and

120
00:07:21.980 --> 00:07:26.340
therefore you're not gonna, hopefully,
make any attempt to break it.

121
00:07:26.340 --> 00:07:29.160
Or at least it's going to slow
you down substantially, so

122
00:07:29.160 --> 00:07:30.920
that's really the magic of this.

123
00:07:30.920 --> 00:07:34.920
But as we go back in history
it's the same type of thing.

124
00:07:34.920 --> 00:07:39.250
Is that they've had all these different
techniques of hiding information in

125
00:07:39.250 --> 00:07:42.110
a place where you would not go looking for
it.

126
00:07:42.110 --> 00:07:45.816
And therefore someone can just pass
completely undetected with a secret

127
00:07:45.816 --> 00:07:47.220
message or whatever it is.

128
00:07:47.220 --> 00:07:50.487
>> It makes me think of the spy
world always, cuz as a spy,

129
00:07:50.487 --> 00:07:53.839
there's always that chance
that you might get caught.

130
00:07:53.839 --> 00:07:57.661
And if I've got a thumb drive full of
encrypted files, I'm gonna have a hard

131
00:07:57.661 --> 00:08:01.480
time saying that I'm not a spy, or
whatever the case may be, but if I've got

132
00:08:01.480 --> 00:08:05.560
a thumb drive full of pictures, maybe
part of my cover is I'm a tourist, right?

133
00:08:05.560 --> 00:08:08.166
And I've got all these pictures
of different tourist spots and

134
00:08:08.166 --> 00:08:10.279
things like that, and
maybe I can get away with it,

135
00:08:10.279 --> 00:08:13.500
because they don't see that there's
data embedded in those images.

136
00:08:13.500 --> 00:08:17.500
So this is really when encryption does
a good job of keeping the bad guys out, or

137
00:08:17.500 --> 00:08:21.780
keeping it only to the authorized
people of that information.

138
00:08:21.780 --> 00:08:26.500
But steganography is when we have to hide
the fact that we've got the information in

139
00:08:26.500 --> 00:08:29.230
the first place,
is really what it comes down to.

140
00:08:29.230 --> 00:08:33.590
>> Yeah, it's almost adding on if you
look at the CIA triad and you've got,

141
00:08:33.590 --> 00:08:38.380
you look at the confidentiality part,
cryptography very clearly does that.

142
00:08:38.380 --> 00:08:40.938
Anything we've seen so far does that.

143
00:08:40.938 --> 00:08:45.839
Steganography you could say
adds another C to the CIA, and

144
00:08:45.839 --> 00:08:48.848
it does concealment on top of that.

145
00:08:48.848 --> 00:08:50.810
So, it's not just keeping it confidential.

146
00:08:50.810 --> 00:08:52.940
It completely conceals it.

147
00:08:52.940 --> 00:08:57.710
So, it's adding an extra layer, and
so that's always been the trick and

148
00:08:57.710 --> 00:09:02.570
the magic with steganography, and
no matter what form you look at it,

149
00:09:02.570 --> 00:09:05.420
it's always been the same way,
and you're right.

150
00:09:05.420 --> 00:09:09.930
A lot of it has been in the spy role
though, and transmit information and

151
00:09:09.930 --> 00:09:14.400
secret messages that way, and
some of the earliest examples of it.

152
00:09:14.400 --> 00:09:19.300
They had, it was known a couple thousand

153
00:09:19.300 --> 00:09:24.580
years ago that they would send
messages through couriers,

154
00:09:24.580 --> 00:09:29.290
and the Roman Empire and places like that,

155
00:09:29.290 --> 00:09:32.913
they would just grab someone
that was unfortunate.

156
00:09:32.913 --> 00:09:35.600
>> [LAUGH]
>> They just grab someone-

157
00:09:35.600 --> 00:09:37.588
>> So, need the whole volunteer thing and

158
00:09:37.588 --> 00:09:40.310
if I stand in a row and
they say we need a volunteer and-

159
00:09:40.310 --> 00:09:40.890
>> Yeah.

160
00:09:40.890 --> 00:09:42.350
>> everybody else steps back and
you reach that deal right there.

161
00:09:42.350 --> 00:09:44.060
>> Yep-
>> [LAUGH]

162
00:09:44.060 --> 00:09:45.230
>> which still works today by the way.

163
00:09:45.230 --> 00:09:46.680
>> Yeah, it does.

164
00:09:46.680 --> 00:09:51.888
But they would just get somebody,
and what they would do is usually

165
00:09:51.888 --> 00:09:56.550
there was a server or
something like that of that standing.

166
00:09:56.550 --> 00:10:00.486
And what they were, one of the techniques
that they used was they would shave

167
00:10:00.486 --> 00:10:03.500
their head, and
then tattoo the message on their scalp and

168
00:10:03.500 --> 00:10:06.100
let their hair grow back,
and then send them out.

169
00:10:06.100 --> 00:10:07.390
And-
>> Wow.

170
00:10:07.390 --> 00:10:10.953
>> it doesn't work as fast as
we would want nowadays but then,

171
00:10:10.953 --> 00:10:15.232
the way the order of battle and other
stuff worked was just a lot slower so

172
00:10:15.232 --> 00:10:18.600
if you're sending information
that way it would work.

173
00:10:18.600 --> 00:10:22.577
And all you have to do is just tell
that person get to this point,

174
00:10:22.577 --> 00:10:26.707
and they're gonna be able to walk
right on through wherever, and

175
00:10:26.707 --> 00:10:31.310
unless someone knows that it's there,
they're not gonna go looking.

176
00:10:31.310 --> 00:10:32.180
>> Right, yeah.

177
00:10:32.180 --> 00:10:34.047
[CROSSTALK]
>> And

178
00:10:34.047 --> 00:10:35.180
the other guy at the other end
has to get his head shaved and.

179
00:10:35.180 --> 00:10:35.930
>> Yeah.

180
00:10:35.930 --> 00:10:40.020
>> As an example, and I know you got
some other really good examples of where

181
00:10:40.020 --> 00:10:44.060
we see this type of, I don't know if
I really wanna call it encryption.

182
00:10:44.060 --> 00:10:48.452
So where we see steganography, maybe they
didn't call it steganography at the time,

183
00:10:48.452 --> 00:10:50.930
but you've got some really
good examples here.

184
00:10:50.930 --> 00:10:55.228
>> Yeah, it's really tough when you
get into this, cuz yeah, there's so

185
00:10:55.228 --> 00:10:59.890
many just neat examples of this and
little things they've done along the way.

186
00:10:59.890 --> 00:11:03.764
One I had mentioned in a prior episode,
and

187
00:11:03.764 --> 00:11:08.929
I believe I had also mentioned
it in our forensics class,

188
00:11:08.929 --> 00:11:11.850
just a kind of a piece of trivia.

189
00:11:11.850 --> 00:11:15.980
Was one of the techniques that had
been developed both in Europe and

190
00:11:15.980 --> 00:11:18.928
in Japan,
was the one of using boiled eggs, and

191
00:11:18.928 --> 00:11:23.230
using a special ink that would put
the stuff on the surface of the egg.

192
00:11:23.230 --> 00:11:27.794
Then all you had to do is just peel it,
and either read it directly, or you dunked

193
00:11:27.794 --> 00:11:32.450
it in a dye, and it revealed it, and so
that's plain and simple steganography.

194
00:11:32.450 --> 00:11:36.030
If you're doing it with an ink that
can't be seen unless you dye it, and

195
00:11:36.030 --> 00:11:41.500
unless you peel that shell off, then you
know you've got a pretty effective method.

196
00:11:41.500 --> 00:11:44.120
Someone's gonna have to search
every egg that comes by.

197
00:11:44.120 --> 00:11:45.680
>> [LAUGH]
>> Can you imagine that?

198
00:11:45.680 --> 00:11:48.690
It just, it's gonna be a real,
real big pain.

199
00:11:48.690 --> 00:11:53.270
And then on top of it, they'll have to
know the solution that they have to

200
00:11:53.270 --> 00:11:57.920
mix to actually reveal that message,
or make it develop.

201
00:11:57.920 --> 00:12:04.640
So, you've got kind of a tall order there,
and it worked for a good long time.

202
00:12:04.640 --> 00:12:09.480
So it's just one of the interesting ones
that the ancient world came up with.

203
00:12:09.480 --> 00:12:13.463
Then they also different ones,
tattoos as mentioned,

204
00:12:13.463 --> 00:12:17.030
tattooing the head was an old technique.

205
00:12:17.030 --> 00:12:21.218
They still use it,
not necessarily tattooing the head for

206
00:12:21.218 --> 00:12:26.270
that reason, but you will get,
the world of people getting tattoos.

207
00:12:26.270 --> 00:12:29.896
You will see that some of the tattoos
do carry meanings to only those

208
00:12:29.896 --> 00:12:33.480
people that would know that
meaning's there in the first place.

209
00:12:33.480 --> 00:12:34.020
>> Right.

210
00:12:34.020 --> 00:12:39.039
>> To everyone else, it looks like
a piece of artwork, or what have you,

211
00:12:39.039 --> 00:12:43.310
but the ones that actually kind
of know what the end deal is.

212
00:12:43.310 --> 00:12:45.980
The ones I think are like
the jailhouse tattoo-

213
00:12:45.980 --> 00:12:46.600
>> Yeah.

214
00:12:46.600 --> 00:12:49.970
>> stuff like that, you know the tear,
and I guess there's a spider web one.

215
00:12:49.970 --> 00:12:51.140
I've never been to prison, sorry.

216
00:12:51.140 --> 00:12:54.782
>> I know some of you have
mentioned the show CSI, for

217
00:12:54.782 --> 00:12:59.140
those of us here in the US,
CSI Crime Scene Investigation.

218
00:12:59.140 --> 00:13:02.757
They've got a new series they've
